choices.text: High voltage burns

questions.text: A 45-year-old electrician is brought to the emergency department after sustaining injuries from a high-voltage electrical line during work. Upon examination, the patient has areas of skin that are leathery with a distinctive pattern that resembles crocodile skin. The areas are primarily localized along the pathway of the current across his body. The medical officer is discussing the case with residents and asks them to identify the condition that typically presents this type of skin appearance. What is the "crocodile skin" appearance commonly associated with?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High voltage burns

 

Option C:

 

The "crocodile skin" appearance is characteristic of high voltage electrical burns. This pattern results from the intense heat generated by the electrical current, which causes full-thickness skin damage that coagulates and contracts the skin, often leaving a patterned effect that resembles the hide of a crocodile.

 

 

Exogenous electric burns

 

  • The term exogenous burns is used If the contact with electric source is not good or is less firm (or in case of high voltage source there may not even be any contact but the victim is just nearby).
  • The current jumps the gap between the source and the skin in the form of a spark and causes the outer skin keratin to melt over a small area.  On cooling,  the  keratin  gets  condensed  into  a  hard brownish nodule and this is termed as the so-called spark burn or Flash burn.
  • In cases of High Voltage sources, the currents can jump several millimeters across air and cause multiple spark burns over a large area. This molten keratin over these area fuses into multiple hard brownish nodules on cooling and resembles skin of the crocodile called crocodile burns.

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. Drowning does not result in such patterns on the skin; changes related to drowning include wrinkling or washing away of the superficial skin layers.

 

Option B. Mummification refers to the dehydration of the body after death, leading to dry, shrunken, and leathery skin.

 

Option D. Electric shocks can cause a variety of skin appearances depending on the voltage, but the specific "crocodile skin" appearance is typically associated with high voltage injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crocodile skin appearance is a kind of exogenous burns seen due to Electric current in high voltage sources when there is no direct contact with body. The term electric shock is used when the person touches an electrical source, whereas, Crocodile skin appearance occurs when the person is near the high voltage source but not in direct contact. 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 330-331

choices.text: Excoriation of skin by excreta

questions.text: In clinical practice, physicians often encounter various skin conditions that can mimic the appearance of abrasions, making accurate diagnosis challenging. Some of these conditions present features similar to abrasions due to their superficial nature or pattern of injury. However, one of the following conditions is not typically associated with features that mimic abrasions. Which of these conditions does NOT typically present with features resembling abrasions?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Frostbite

 

Option D:

 

Frostbite is infarction of the peripheral digits with oedema, redness and later necrosis of the tissue beyond a line of inflammatory demarcation. It may affect only the skin or may extend deeply. It occurs due to exposure to greater extremes of cold (-2.5°C), develops more rapidly and in addition to the extremities, it frequently affects other parts, e.g., nose, ears and the face. In frostbite, necrosis with blister formation and gangrene occurs. Skin becomes hard and black in about two weeks.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ant bite - Ant bites can cause localized inflammation and skin damage that may superficially resemble an abrasion.

 

Option B. Excoriation of skin by excreta - This can lead to superficial skin damage due to chemical irritation, which may appear similar to an abrasion.

 

Option C. Pressure sore - Pressure sores, particularly in their initial stages, can resemble abrasions due to superficial skin damage caused by prolonged pressure.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Frostbite is generally not categorized as a condition that mimics abrasions. Conditions that mimic abrasions include ant bites, skin excoriation caused by contact with excreta, pressure sores, and others.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 317

questions.text: A case is presented involving a victim found in the aftermath of a fire. The forensic resident is tasked with determining whether the burns found on the body occurred before or after death – a crucial aspect in distinguishing between accidental death and possible foul play. During the autopsy, the resident focuses on identifying the most definitive indicator of antemortem (before death) burns. Which among the following is considered the surest sign of an antemortem burn?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Soot inside trachea

 

Option B:

 

All the given choices are signs of Antemortem burn, however, the most specific and the most definite sign of antemortem burn is soot and carbon particles in larynx, trachea and bronchioles. Because without respiratory activity the soot particles cannot enter the respiratory tract, hence it is the surest sign of antemortem burn.

 

However, soot usually disappears by the 2nd day of hospitalization.

 

Signs of antemortem burn: - Soot inside respiratory tract; Line of redness (hyperemia); Carboxyhemoglobin in blood; Albumin and chloride in vesicles; Infection; Healing granulation tissues

 

Antemortem burns Vs Postmortem burns

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Line of redness - Can be seen in both antemortem and postmortem burns. It’s a zone of hyperemia (line of redness), which varies in width, but is usually five to twenty mm. It is present at the edge of the burnt area, except in cases of immediate death. It is due to oedema of tissues and capillary dilatation and merges with the edge of the burn which may show blistering or charring. It is permanent and persists after death. Heat applied up to one hour after death can produce a red line of erythema.

 

Option C. Carboxyhemoglobin in blood - Suggestive but not conclusive of antemortem burn. If the hemoglobin saturation is >10% CO, then the person was alive and inhaled the air during the fire. If death occurs due to the toxicity of CO, the blood carboxyhemoglobin (COHb) saturation is in the range of 50–80%. The COHb saturation level will not be artificially elevated in a dead person by being in or near a fire.

 

Option D. Elevated enzymes - It is specific to antemortem burns, but it is demonstrable as a diminishing stainability, and becomes visible in 1–4 h after wounding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of soot inside the trachea is a sure sign of an antemortem burn, indicating that the person was breathing during the fire, inhaling smoke and soot.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 327

questions.text: In a hospital burn unit, you are tasked with assessing a patient who has sustained extensive burns. The patient presents with burns on several distinct body areas: the neck, front and back of the chest, both upper limbs (excluding the hands), front and back of both thighs, and the genitalia. Utilizing the Rule of Nines, what is the percentage of Total Body Surface Area burnt?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 55%

 

Explanation:

 

Wallace Rule of Nine - 9% for the head and neck (head 7%, neck 2% ); 9% for each upper limb (arm 4%, forearm 3%, hand 2%), 9% for the front of each lower limb; 9% for the back of each lower limb (thigh 10%, leg 5%, foot 3% for each lower limb); 9% for the front of chest; 9% for the back of chest; 9% for the front of the abdomen; and 9% for the back of abdomen, 99% of the body. The remaining one percent is for the external genitalia.

 

Calculation - Using the Rule of Nines:

 

  • Neck (2%)
  • Anterior and posterior chest (9% each)
  • Entire arms except hands (7% each)
  • Anterior and posterior thighs (10% each)
  • Genitalia (1%)

 

Total = 2% + 18% + 14% + 20% + 1% = 55%

 

Other Rules for calculating percentage of burn –

 

  • Rule of palm (size of palm is considered as 1%). Palmar surface can be used to estimate small burns (< 15% TBSA) or very large burns (> 85%, when unburnt skin is counted).
  • Lund & Browder Formula (for accurate estimation of percentage of burn in children, as Wallace’s Rule of Nines is not accurate in children because of the relatively larger head surface area) - In children < 1 year, head is 18% of TBSA and each leg is 14% of TBSA. Trunk and arms represent the same percentages as in adults. For each year above 1 year old, add 0.5% to each leg and reduce 1.0% to the head until adult values are reached.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wallace Rule of Nine representation –

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 321

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: A forensic expert encounters a case where a body was discovered after being exposed to intense heat. Upon examination, he notes a hematoma in the extradural space. This type of hematoma can be confused with extradural hemorrhage. What structure is typically responsible for the rupture that leads to a heat hematoma in the extradural space?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Venous sinuses

 

Option B:

 

Heat hematoma occurs when the head has been exposed to intense heat. It occurs in extradural space mostly due to rupture of dural venous sinuses and emissary veins because of boiling blood. Since the hematoma occurs extradurally, it is sometimes confused with Extradural hemorrhage. But they can easily be differentiated by various characteristics. The source of bleeding in Extradural hemorrhage is middle meningeal artery.

 

The most common site of Heat hematoma - Parietotemporal region.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Middle meningeal artery - More commonly associated with extradural hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Extradural capillaries - Less likely to cause significant hematomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heat hematomas in the extradural space are typically caused by the rupture of venous sinuses.

 

Heat Hematoma Vs EDH

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 324

choices.text: Loose contact with low voltage current
Firm contact with low voltage current
Loose contact with high voltage current
Firm contact with high voltage current

questions.text: In a recent case handled by a forensic team, they encountered a victim with unusual patterned burns, as shown in below picture. The team is assessing the circumstances leading to these distinctive burns, to understand the nature of the incident. What specific condition leads to the formation of this burn?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loose contact with high voltage current

 

Option C:

 

Crocodile burns are typically associated with loose contact with high voltage current. These burns are characterized by their patterned appearance, resembling crocodile skin, and occur when skin makes intermittent contact with a high voltage source. High tension electric currents produce multiple punched out lesions due to arcing from the conductor to the body without direct contact. This leads to the distinctive patterned burns.

 

Flash burns are also called exogenous burns as the flame is produced outside the body. The flash can ignite the patient’s clothes causing flame burns along with singeing of hair. Flash burns are due to loose contact with air gap.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Loose contact with low voltage current: Low voltage burns usually result in less severe, localized injuries without the characteristic patterned appearance.

 

Option B. Firm contact with low voltage current: Joule burn/ electric mark is produced by Firm contact with low voltage current This caused more localized and deep burns. It is endogenous thermal burn due to the heat generated in the body from electricity. These marks are round or oval, shallow craters or may resemble the broken blister. When contact is more prolonged, the skin in the mark becomes brown and with further contact, there may be charring. lf the conductor contains copper; the electric mark can have a bright green color. Occasionally, the mark may have a distinctive pattern, that of the shape of the conductor especially where this is a linear wire or a shaped metal object. Where the tip of the wire or rod is at right angle to the skin, the mark may be present as a circular hole, penetrating skin, muscle and even bone, so as to simulate a bullet hole.

 

 

Option D. Firm contact with high voltage current: Firm contact with a high voltage source can cause severe and deep burns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crocodile burns associated with loose contact with high voltage electrical injuries. Joule burn is produced by Firm contact with low voltage current.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 330-331

choices.text: Application of liquid above 60°C
Clothes protect the injuries over the covered areas
Lines of redness are present
Singeing of body hairs is absent

questions.text: During a hospital-based review of burn injuries, a forensic medicine resident examines a patient. To determine the nature of the burns, the expert reviews key characteristics of scald injuries. Which statement is FALSE regarding scald injuries?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clothes protect the injuries over the covered areas

 

Option B:

 

A scald is an injury which results from the application of liquid above 60°C or from steam.

 

The destruction does not extend as deeply as in burns. Water at 70°C can cause full thickness scalds of the skin in one second of contact. Redness appears at once and blistering will take place within a few minutes. Blisters have a hyperemic zone around them. There is a reddening and swelling of the papillae in the floor of the blister.

 

Scalds show soddening and bleaching but do not singe the hair, and do not blacken or char the skin.

 

  • Degrees of Scalds: (1) Erythema by Vaso paralysis. (2) Blister formation due to increased permeability of the capillaries. (3) Necrosis of the dermis.
  •  The injury is limited to the area of contact and is more severe at the point of the initial contact.
  • Scalding can occur through clothing. Clothes worsen the damage by prolonging contact with hot liquid and reducing the cooling effect of evaporation.
  •  Sticky liquids, such as syrup, oils and tar cause more severe scalds than hot water. The scalded skin may swell and exude serum. Scars of scalds are much thinner than those of deep bums and cause less contraction and disfigurement.
  •  Death usually occurs from shock, fluid and electrolyte disturbance and secondary infection.
  •  Scalds are usually accidental due to bursting of hot water bottles, bursting of boilers, splashing of fluid from cooking utensils, or pulling over saucepans or kettles by children, etc. (splash burn).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Application of liquid above 60°C: This is true. Scald injuries typically occur from the application of hot liquids at temperatures above 60°C.

 

Option C. Lines of redness are present: This is true. Scald injuries often show clear demarcation lines, indicating the area of contact with the hot liquid.

 

Option D. Singeing of body hairs is absent: This is also true. Singeing of body hairs is generally associated with flame burns, not scalds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scald injuries result from application of liquid above 60°C or from steam. Clothes worsen the damage by prolonging the contact with hot liquid and reducing the cooling effect of evaporation.  Line of redness are present as that of dry burn, but it is absent in chemical injuries. Singeing of hairs and charring are absent unlike dry burn.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 329

questions.text: A forensic expert is examining hair samples collected from a deceased individual who was suspected to have died from an electrical accident. The hair samples show multiple pit-like defects. What is the most likely cause of these hair characteristics?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Electrocution

 

Option C:

 

Pit-like defects on human hairs are characteristic findings in cases of electrocution. These defects are caused by the intense heat generated by the passage of electric current, leading to localized damage to the hair shafts.

 

Some important Pointers Electrocution –

 

  • Death is more likely to occur, if the brainstem or heart is in the direct path of the current.
  • Severity is directly proportional to the duration of current flow. For an electric shock to occur, the body must be in contact with both the positive and negative pole or with the earth
  • Ventricular fibrillation (low voltage current)—most common cause of death
  • Rigor mortis appear early, dark blue-red postmortem staining is well developed
  • A very important PM finding is local hemorrhages and/or tears in the muscles.
  • Pit like defect on the surface of hair due to arcing of current
  • Molten metal derived from the electrode called current pearl may be found deep in the soft tissue.
  • Molten calcium phosphate from bone called bone pearls or wax drippings are detected in radiological investigation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Starvation: While malnutrition can affect hair quality, leading to thinning or brittle hair, it does not cause pit-like defects.

 

Option B. Negroes: Hair characteristics vary among different ethnic groups, negroes hair are black or dark brown in color, flat shaped, shaft diameter is wide, irregular pigmentation,  medulla is fragmented or absent. Pit-like defects are not a feature associated with any particular race or ethnicity.

 

Option D. Flash burns: Flash burns are also called exogenous burns as the flame is produced outside the body. The flash can ignite the patient’s clothes causing flame burns along with singeing or burning of hair, but the specific pit-like defects are more characteristic of electrocution rather than general burn injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that pit-like defects on human hairs are indicative of electrocution, reflecting the intense heat and damage caused by electric current.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 332

questions.text: A 30-year-old construction worker's body is brought in by the police after an accident at a construction site. He was found unconscious near an electrical panel. Examination reveals signs of severe electrical injury. An X-ray of the affected area shows a distinctive pattern resembling 'bone pearls' or 'wax drippings'. This radiological finding is pathognomonic for a specific type of injury. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this X-ray finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Electrocution

 

Option D:

 

The occurrence of 'bone pearls' or changes that resemble 'wax drippings' on bones is indicative of death due to electrocution. This unique feature occurs when the high voltage of electricity passing through the body causes intense heat, leading to the calcination of bones. Heat generated by current melts Ca phosphate leads to round dense foci on X-ray - Bone pearls/ wax drippings, zigzag microfractures, bone necrosis. These changes are distinct and can be used as a significant forensic marker in cases of electrocution. Death in these cases may be due to vagal stimulation.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Burns: While severe burns can cause damage to bones, they typically do not produce the specific 'bone pearl' or 'wax dripping' appearance.

 

Option B. Scalds: Scalding affects primarily the skin and superficial tissues, and does not result in the characteristic bone changes associated with electrocution.

 

Option C. Lightning: Although lightning strikes cause severe thermal injury, the specific changes seen in electrocution, such as 'bone pearls' or 'wax drippings', are not typical of lightning injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 'bone pearls' or 'wax drippings' pattern on an X-ray is pathognomonic for high-voltage electrocution, a critical diagnostic feature that differentiates it from other types of thermal injuries such as burns, scalds, or lightning strikes.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 332

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: A 35-year-old electrician presents to the emergency department after sustaining an injury from a high-voltage electrical line. On examination, the patient has deep, charred lesions on the hands and forearms. Given the nature of the injury and the observed characteristics of the burn, which type of burn is typically associated with high voltage electrical contact?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Full thickness

 

Option B:

 

High voltage contact burns are typically classified as full thickness burns. These burns occur due to the passage of a high voltage electrical current through the body, causing extensive damage to the skin and underlying tissues. Full thickness burns are characterized by complete destruction of the epidermis and dermis, often affecting deeper tissues like muscles and bones.

 

Clinically, burns are classified as first degree (superficial) burns, second degree (partial and deep partial) burns and third degree (full thickness) burns

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Deep partial thickness: While deep, these burns do not involve the complete destruction of the dermis as seen in full thickness burns.

 

Option C. Superficial burn: Superficial burns affect only the outer layer of the skin and are not representative of the severe damage caused by high voltage electrical currents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High voltage contact burn is Full Thickness Burn

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 332

questions.text: In the context of electrical injuries, understanding the relative resistance of different tissues to electric current is crucial for assessing the extent and severity of injury. Among the following organs or tissues, which one is considered the most resistant to electric current?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bone

 

Option A:

 

Bone is the most resistant organ to electric current. Its high resistance is due to its relatively low water content and dense structure, making it less conductive compared to other body tissues. This characteristic can play a significant role in determining the path of electrical current through the body in cases of electrocution.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Skin: While the skin does offer resistance to electric current, particularly when dry, it is less resistant than bone. The resistance of skin can vary significantly based on its condition (e.g., wet or dry, intact or broken).

 

Option C. Blood Vessel: Blood vessels, due to their fluid content, have lower resistance and are more likely to conduct electric current.

 

Option D. Muscle: Muscle tissue, like blood vessels, has a high water content and is more conductive than bone, making it less resistant to electric current.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing that bone has the highest resistance due to its low water content and dense structure is important for assessing the potential pathways of electrical injury and the resultant damage in various tissues.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg

questions.text: In patients suffering from severe burns or trauma, a specific type of stress ulcer known as Curling’s ulcer may develop. This condition is a serious complication often observed in the acute phase following the injury. Which part of the gastrointestinal tract is most likely to be affected by Curling’s ulcer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Duodenum

 

Option D:

 

Curling's ulcer, a type of stress ulcer, is commonly seen in the first part of duodenum in patients with severe burns, in less than 10% cases, about the tenth day in extensive burns of the body. Curling's ulcers are usually sharply punched-out mucosal defects, which may be superficial or deep.  These ulcers are caused by the physiological stress from the burns, leading to reduced blood flow and mucosal damage in the gastrointestinal tract. The duodenum is particularly susceptible to such changes, making it the most common site for Curling's ulcers in burn patients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Esophagus: While the esophagus can be affected by stress ulcers, Curling's ulcers are more specifically associated with the duodenum in the context of burn injuries.

 

Option B. Stomach: Stress ulcers can also occur in the stomach, but the typical location for Curling's ulcers in burn patients is the duodenum.

 

Option C. Colon: Curling's ulcers are characteristic of the upper gastrointestinal tract and are not commonly found in the colon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Curling’s ulcers may be seen in severely burnt patient’s gastric atrium and first part of duodenum after 72 h (3–10 days post survival). It develops due to mucosal ischemia as a result of stress and shock, and not related to acidity.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 327

choices.text: Between skull and dura mater
Between skull and pericranium
Between scalp and pericranium

questions.text: During a forensic examination, a deceased individual is found to have a heat hematoma. The forensic pathologist discusses the typical location of such a hematoma with medical students observing the autopsy. Where is a heat hematoma typically located?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Between skull and dura mater

 

Option B:

 

Heat haematoma - Occurs when the head has been exposed to intense heat, sufficient to cause charring of the skull.

 

It has the appearance of extradural hemorrhage, but is not accompanied by any signs of injury by blunt force. It consists of a soft, friable clot of light chocolate color, and may be pink, if the blood contains CO. The clot has a honeycomb appearance due to bubbles of steam produced by heat. The adjacent brain shows hardening and discoloration from the heat.

 

The parietotemporal region is the most common site and sometimes frontal or occipital region. It may be due to blood being boiled from the diploic layer of bone through emissary veins and venous sinus which rupture or shrinkage of meninges and brain.

 

Heat haematoma will contain carboxyhemoglobin, but extradural hemorrhage caused by injury before the fire began, will not show carboxyhemoglobin.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Inside the brain: This would be more indicative of an intracerebral hematoma, which is different from a heat (epidural) hematoma.

 

Option C. Between skull and pericranium: This space is not typically where a heat (epidural) hematoma forms. Hematomas in this location would be more superficial and not involve the meningeal arteries.

 

Option D. Between scalp and pericranium: Hematomas in this location are typically subgaleal hematomas, which are different from epidural (heat) hematomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heat hematoma typically located between skull and dura mater

 

EDH due to burn Vs blunt forces –

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 324

choices.text: Small and multiple wounds
Nerves and vessels are visible in floor
Seen only over scalp

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious near a fire outbreak site. He was reportedly trapped in a confined space with intense heat for a brief period before being rescued. On examination, the patient is responsive but in severe distress. You notice a complex wound on his head. Based on the clinical scenario described, which feature of the observed head wound is most indicative of a heat rupture?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nerves and vessels are visible in floor

 

Option C:

 

A key distinguishing feature of a heat rupture is the visibility of nerves and vessels in the floor of the wound. Heat ruptures typically occur due to thermal effects on the skin and underlying tissues, causing them to split and reveal underlying structures like nerves and blood vessels. This is in contrast to incised wounds, which are usually the result of sharp force trauma and tend to have cleaner, more defined edges without necessarily exposing the underlying structures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Margins well-defined: While well-defined margins can be seen in various types of wounds, they are not specifically indicative of heat ruptures.

 

Option B. Small and multiple wounds: This description can apply to various injuries but is not particularly characteristic of heat ruptures.

 

Option D. Seen only over scalp: Heat ruptures can occur in the scalp due to the expansion and rupture of the skull and scalp tissue, but the visibility of nerves and vessels in the wound floor is a more specific indicator.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing that the visibility of nerves and vessels in the floor of a wound is indicative of a heat rupture. wound is characterized by its unusual depth, revealing underlying structures i.e. the nerves and blood vessels are distinctly visible at the base of the wound. There is no active bleeding, and the margins of the wound are irregular.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 323

choices.text: Cannot differentiate between ante- or postmortem burns
Indicates defense by the victim

questions.text: During a forensic investigation, you are examining the body of a victim recovered from a burnt building. You note that the body is in a peculiar posture, with the upper limbs flexed at the elbows, fists clenched, and legs flexed. This posture is often described as the "pugilistic attitude." As a forensic expert, you recall that this specific body posture is frequently observed in burn victims. What does the "pugilistic attitude" posture in burn victims typically indicate about the timing of the burns?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cannot differentiate between ante- or postmortem burns

 

Option C:

 

The pugilistic attitude is a phenomenon where the body assumes a boxer-like, flexed posture as a result of heat-induced muscle contraction. This posture can occur in both antemortem and postmortem burn cases and is a result of the effects of heat on the muscles and tendons, causing them to contract. Therefore, it cannot be used reliably to differentiate between burns that occurred before or after death.

 

 

Cause: Due to coagulation of proteins of muscles and dehydration which causes contraction. Flexor muscles being bulkier than extensor, contract more and a position of generalized flexion is adopted. It occurs whether the person was alive or dead at the time of burning and has therefore no medico-legal significance

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Indicates antemortem burns: This posture can also occur in postmortem burns, so it is not exclusively indicative of antemortem burns.

 

Option B. Indicates postmortem burns: Similarly, it can also occur in antemortem burns, so it is not exclusively indicative of postmortem burns.

 

Option D. Indicates defense by the victim: The pugilistic attitude is a postural change due to heat effects, not a defensive action by the victim.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pugilistic attitude (boxing, fencing or defense attitude): It is due to heat stiffening. The legs are flexed at the hips and knees, the arms are flexed at the elbows and held out in front of the body and the fingers are hooked like claws.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 322-323

questions.text: In assessing the extent of burns, the “rule of palms” is often utilized. According to this rule, the surface area of the palm of a patient, including fingers, represents what percentage of the total body surface area?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1%

 

Explanation:

 

The "rule of palms" is a quick assessment tool used in burn injuries, where the palm of the patient's hand (including fingers) is estimated to represent approximately 1% of the total body surface area. This method is useful for rapidly estimating the extent of a burn.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rule of palm (size of palm is considered as 1%). Palmar surface can be used to estimate small burns (< 15% TBSA) or very large burns (> 85%, when unburnt skin is counted).

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 321

questions.text: A 50-year-old male is brought in the emergency after sustaining burns in an industrial accident. The burns cover a significant portion of his body, and he shows signs of shock. In adults, a minimum of what percentage of total body surface area (TBSA) burns is typically associated with circulatory collapse?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 15%

 

Explanation:

 

Circulatory collapse in adults is generally associated with burns covering a minimum of 15% of the total body surface area. Burns of this extent can lead to significant fluid loss and shock, necessitating immediate medical intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Circulatory collapse may occur with 15% of burns of total body surface area.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 321

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic after sustaining a burn to her hand from a campfire during a camping trip. On examination, the burned area on her hand is noted to be reddened and blistered. What is the most likely classification of her burn injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Second degree superficial

 

Option B:

 

The presentation of a reddened and blistered area is indicative of a second-degree superficial burn. These burns involve the epidermis and part of the dermis. The presence of blisters, along with the reddened appearance of the skin, are characteristic features of this type of burn.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. First degree: These are more superficial and  typically present with redness but without blistering.

 

Option C. Second degree deep: While these can have blisters, the damage is more extensive.

 

Option D. Third degree: These involve the full thickness of the skin and often appear white, charred, or leathery, without blisters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The blistering of skin is associated with superficial second-degree burns.

 

Classification of burns –

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 320

questions.text: A group of miners is brought to the ESI hospital emergency department after working in an underground mine with insufficient ventilation on a hot day. Several of the miners are experiencing painful muscle spasms, particularly in their legs. This condition, commonly seen in individuals exposed to high temperatures and physical exertion, is known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Heat cramps

 

Option B:

 

Heat cramps (miner's cramps, stoker's cramps or fireman's cramps): They are caused by a rapid dehydration of body through the loss of water and salt in the sweat. It is seen in workers in high temperature when sweating has been profuse. The onset is usually sudden. Severe and painful paroxysmal cramps affecting the muscles of the arms, legs and abdomen occur. The face is flushed, the pupils dilated and the patient complains of dizziness, tinnitus, headache and vomiting. Intravenous injection of saline gives rapid relief.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Heat collapse: This term is not typically used in medical terminology. Collapse due to heat would more likely be related to heat exhaustion or heat stroke, both of which have distinct clinical presentations different from muscle cramps.

 

Option C. Sunstroke: Also known as heat stroke, it is a severe form of heat illness that occurs when the body's temperature regulation fails, as a body temperature exceeding 40°C (104°F). Symptoms include high body temperature, altered mental state, and possibly organ damage. It does not primarily present with muscle cramps. The common complications are rhabdomyolysis, pancreatitis, cerebral edema due to the systemic effects of severe hyperthermia.

 

Option D. Heat exhaustion: This is a heat-related illness that can occur after prolonged exposure to high temperatures and inadequate or unbalanced replacement of fluids. Symptoms include heavy sweating, weakness, and possible nausea, but not typically isolated muscle cramps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classification of Thermal injuries –

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 318-19

questions.text: A search and rescue team finds an individual in a snowy environment showing unusual behavior. Despite the freezing temperatures, the person has removed several layers of clothing. The team is aware that this behavior, known as “paradoxical undressing,” is a phenomenon seen in certain medical conditions. “Paradoxical undressing” is most commonly seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypothermia

 

Option B:

 

Paradoxical undressing is a phenomenon observed in late-stage hypothermia. As hypothermia progresses, individuals may become confused and experience a false sensation of warmth, leading them to undress. This behavior exacerbates their exposure to the cold and can accelerate the onset of fatal hypothermia.

 

Note - ‘Hide and die’ syndrome: In some hypothermic deaths, bodies are found in some strange places—under a bed or bench, on a shelf or behind a wardrobe, or alternatively may pull down household articles into a heap on top, which may give the impression of their attempt to ‘hide’ (protective ‘burrow-like’ or ‘cave-like’ situation). This may also lead to the assumption of a homicide or robbery. It is due to mental confusion from hypothermia and may be related to hibernation reflex.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hyperthermia: This condition involves an abnormally high body temperature (>40°C), often due to external heat sources or medical conditions. While hyperthermia can cause confusion and disorientation, it does not typically lead to "paradoxical undressing."

 

Option C. Transvestism: This term refers to the practice of dressing and acting in a style or manner traditionally associated with another gender. It is a gender expression and is unrelated to "paradoxical undressing."

 

Option D. Immersion syndrome: Also known as immersion foot or trench foot, this condition results from prolonged exposure to wet and cold conditions. It is characterized by pain, swelling, and cold, damp skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paradoxical undressing as a symptom of late-stage hypothermia, reflecting altered mental status (disoriented, confused and combative) due to severe cold exposure. This sometimes results in the assumption that the deaths are associated with sexual assault (homicide)

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 318

choices.text: Frostbite occurs due to extreme cold exposure
The condition involves the formation of ice crystals within tissues
Rewarming of the affected areas is not part of the treatment protocol
Frostbite commonly affects extremities such as fingers and toes

questions.text: A 30-year-old researcher, working in a polar region, is brought to a field medical station. He was accidentally exposed to extremely low temperatures for an extended period while conducting outdoor experiments. On examination, he exhibits signs of severe frostbite on his fingers, toes, and the tip of his nose. His fingers and toes are pale, cold to the touch, and have a waxy appearance. The medical team prepares to initiate appropriate treatment. In managing the frostbite, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rewarming of the affected areas is not part of the treatment protocol

 

Option C:

 

The statement "Rewarming of the affected areas is not part of the treatment protocol" is incorrect. In managing frostbite, one of the crucial steps is the careful and controlled rewarming of the affected areas. Rewarming is vital to help restore blood flow and minimize further tissue damage. It should be done in a controlled setting to avoid thermal injury and other complications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Frostbite occurs due to extreme cold exposure: This is correct. Frostbite is caused by freezing of the skin and underlying tissues, typically due to exposure to very low temperatures.

 

Option B. The condition involves the formation of ice crystals within tissues: This is correct. Frostbite causes ice crystals to form in the cells, leading to tissue damage.

 

Option D. Frostbite commonly affects extremities such as fingers and toes: This is correct. Extremities, like fingers, toes, and the nose, are more prone to frostbite due to their distance from the core body and reduced blood flow in cold conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the importance of controlled rewarming in the management of frostbite, a condition caused by exposure to extreme cold and characterized by freezing of tissues, especially in extremities.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 317

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male is found lying on a bench in a secluded section of a public park early in the morning by a jogger. He is unresponsive, and emergency services are called. The casualty medical officer at the nearby hospital finds the patient to be in cardiac arrest upon arrival. Resuscitative efforts are initiated, but they are unsuccessful. The patient is pronounced dead, and an autopsy is scheduled. During the autopsy, the medical officer notices the gastric mucosa shows the findings depicted in the picture below:

 

 

What is the probable cause of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypothermia

 

Option A:

 

The image illustrates a common feature in hypothermic deaths, characterized by numerous brown-black acute erosions found in the gastric mucosa. These are known as Wischnewski spots, erosions, or ulcers.

 

The mechanism underlying this phenomenon relates to hypothermia causing increased histamine and serotonin levels, which in turn increases capillary permeability. This elevated capillary permeability disrupts the normal blood flow to the gastric mucosa, leading to the formation of these erosions.

 

Another key autopsy finding in hypothermic deaths is the presence of fat necrosis in the pancreas. This is considered a constant and pathognomonic (disease-specific) feature of such fatalities. Additionally, in cases of hypothermic death, the post-mortem lividity (PML) often appears bright-pink in color due to the presence of oxy-haemoglobin, a form of hemoglobin that is saturated with oxygen.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hyperthermia would not cause Wischnewsky spots and is more likely to present with heatstroke-related changes such as systemic organ failure and possibly hot, dry skin.
 

Option C. Immersion Syndrome, or immersion foot, occurs due to prolonged exposure to wet conditions at non-freezing temperatures and would not present with gastric lesions.

 

Option D. Metallic poison would be more likely to show corrosive effects on the gastric mucosa or specific heavy metal deposits, not the pattern of hemorrhagic lesions observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wischnewsky spots are blackish-brownish color gastric mucosal erosions/ulcerations seen in hypothermia (vary from 1 mm to 2 cm in size and from few to > 100). Similar changes are seen in drug/alcohol abuse and in stress/shock.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 318

questions.text: A 22-year-old mountaineer presents to the emergency department after being rescued from high altitude with complaints of severe pain and numbness in his face following exposure to extreme cold and windy conditions. He reports that the symptoms started a few hours after his protective gear was dislodged by strong winds. Physical examination reveals hard, cold, and pale areas on his face. The medical officer is concerned about frostbite and considers which part of the patient's face is most susceptible to this condition. Which part of the face is most commonly affected by frostbite in these conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nose

 

Option B:

 

Frostbite is most likely to affect body parts that are farther away from the body core and, therefore, have less blood flow. These include: Nose, Ear, Fingers (and Hands), Toes (and Feet).

 

Mnemonic- NEFT

 

Frostbite: Frostbite occurs due to exposure to dry  cold  as  well  as  following  immersion  at temperature below -2.5 0C.  It is commonly seen in mountaineering expeditions. It is of superficial type when only the skin  is  affected  and  deep  type  when subcutaneous fat, muscles, nerves and bones are  affected.

 

Degree of frostbite and their manifestations

 

  1. First degree: Redness of skin
  2. Second degree: There is blister formation
  3. Third degree: Skin and subcutaneous tissue is necrosed
  4. Fourth degree: Total loss of tissue in the exposed area including muscles and bone

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The lips can be affected by cold weather, leading to chapping and frostnip, but they are less likely than the nose to develop severe frostbite due to being less prominent and often protected by being covered or by breathing.

 

Option C. The cheeks are also susceptible to frostbite, but their larger surface area and blood supply generally afford slightly better protection compared to the nose.

 

Option D. Hair cannot develop frostbite as it is composed of keratin and does not contain living tissue or water that can freeze.

 

Educational Objective

 

Frostbite is most likely to affect body parts that are farther away from the body core and, therefore, have less blood flow. These include Nose, Ear, Fingers (and Hands), Toes (and Feet).

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 317-318

questions.text:
While investigating a completely burnt body found in a forest, police officers suspect foul play. The body is badly charred, raising concerns about potential efforts to prevent identification. During the autopsy, the forensic expert conducts a thorough examination to determine the sequence of events. A significant finding in the larynx, as shown in the image, captures the expert's attention. This finding is crucial to determine whether the burns occurred before or after death.

 

 

What does the finding in the larynx suggest?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antemortem Burns

 

Option A:

 

The image shows soot in trachea. So, if there is soot (soot occurs due to deposition of smoke) in the trachea, it indicates that the individual inhaled smoke which means he was alive and breathing during a fire or a period of combustion. This indicates Antemortem burns.

 

PM findings - The presence of carbon particles in the terminal bronchioles on histological examination is absolute proof of life during the fire. The soot is better seen by spreading a thin film of mucus on a clean sheet of white paper. The amount of soot in the air-passages depends on the type of fire, the amount of smoke produced and the duration of survival in the smoke-contaminated atmosphere. Presence of carbon particles and an elevated CO saturation together are absolute proof that the victim was alive when the fire occurred

 

Explanation

 

Option B. Postmortem burns: Soot particles are absent in respiratory tract in postmortem burns because the person cannot inhale, hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option C. Suicidal burns: Soot in respiratory tract only suggests antemortem burns, one cannot say for sure whether its suicidal, accidental or homicidal by just presence of soot in trachea.

 

Option D. Homicidal burns: Soot in respiratory tract only suggests antemortem burns, one cannot say for sure whether its suicidal, accidental or homicidal by just presence of soot in trachea.

 

Educational Objective

 

Difference between antemortem and postmortem burns.

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 325

choices.text: None of the above

questions.text:
During a routine patrol, police officers discover the remains of a victim after a house fire. The body is significantly charred, and the victim's identity is not immediately apparent. At the scene, forensic experts are tasked with determining the nature of the victim's injuries. A careful examination of the head reveals the pattern shown in the image. The pattern is distinct and does not align with common injuries such as incisions or lacerations typically seen in other traumatic circumstances. The forensic expert must use this information to ascertain the cause of the head injury.

 

 

 What does the pattern on the victim's head indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heat rupture

 

Option C:

 

The picture above shows the splits occurring in the skin, has irregular, poorly defined margins. The image shows signs of charring and soot which indicates burn injury. The absence of bleeding rules out incised or lacerated wounds. These splits are called Heat rupture.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incised wound: Incised wounds typically have clean, regular margins and are caused by sharp instruments like knives. There is no sign of bleeding in the image, and also the margins are irregular which rules out incised wound.

 

Option B. Lacerated wound: Lacerated wounds have irregular margins and result from blunt force or tearing, often damaging tissues and causing significant bleeding. Though the margins are irregular in the image, but there is no sign of bleeding which rules out lacerated wounds.

 

Educational Objective

 

Heat Rupture: These are splits occurring in the skin due to contraction of the heated and coagulated tissue. The resultant breaches may be confused with either incised or lacerated wounds but are more commonly confused with lacerated wounds as both have irregular margins. It is usually seen over areas of severe burning, over fleshy areas, like calves and thighs, and over extensor surfaces and joints.

 

Heat ruptures may be distinguished from the effects of violence by:

 

  • Presence of intact nerves, and blood vessels in the split.
  • There is no extravasation of blood in surrounding tissues, since blood vessels are intact.
  • Absence of bruising or other signs of vital reaction in the margins.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 323

questions.text: A team of forensic experts is called to the scene of a structural fire where a body has been discovered among the debris. The body is in a position, which is often referred as 'pugilistic attitude'. The forensic expert knows that this change is a result of a specific physiological process that occurs under extreme heat conditions. What is the pathophysiological process responsible for this 'pugilistic attitude'?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Protein Coagulation

 

Explanation:

 

Heat Stiffening is Shortening and stiffening of muscles due to coagulation of muscle proteins at body temp >65°C.

 

Pugilistic or  Boxer’s  attitude: Sometimes, in Heat stiffening, there are typical Changes in the posture, particularly of the limbs, due to contraction  of  the  muscles  which is called Pugilistic  or  Boxer’s  attitude. There is Flexion of elbows, knees and clenching of hand into a fist. Unlike rigor, heat-stiffening is associated with considerable shortening of muscle fibers.

 

 

Heat stiffening is much more Intense as compared to Rigor Mortis. This heat stiffening cannot be broken down by extending the limbs as in rigor mortis and will persist until decomposition occurs. It Occurs in both Antemortem as well as postmortem burns. If Heat stiffening occurs, then rigor mortis does not occur

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 'pugilistic attitude' is caused by the coagulation of muscle proteins due to the intense heat of a fire. When exposed to high temperatures, muscle proteins denature and contract, pulling the limbs into a characteristic flexed position

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 322-323

choices.text: Round or oval, shallow crater
Joule burn is Hyperemic
Pale raised skin at the margins
Seen at electric contact point

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after an electrical accident at a construction site. He has an entry wound on his right hand and an exit wound on his left foot. On examination, the entry wound presents as a round, shallow crater with pale, raised skin at the margins. The patient is stable, and the wounds are being assessed for further management. The medical officer is explaining to the interns about the characteristics of electrical burns and points out features that are typically expected with this type of injury. Which of the following is not a characteristic of a Joule burn caused by electrical contact?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Joule burn is Hyperemic

 

Option B:

 

In Joule burn, the floor of the burn is pale, surrounded by a pale raised skin. There may only be a mild hyperemia beyond this pale raised skin, but otherwise the joule burn is pale.

 

 

Image shows joule burn

 

Explanation

 

Option A. A round or oval, shallow crater is a characteristic feature of a Joule burn at the contact point with the electric source.

 

Option C. Pale raised skin at the margins is observed due to coagulative necrosis.

 

Option D. These burns are typically seen at the electric contact points where the current enters (and sometimes exits) the body.

 

Educational Objective

 

Joule Burn (Electric Mark) - It occurs at the point where the current enters the body. These electric marks are produced by conversion of electricity into heat within the tissues and, therefore, also called endogenous burns.

 

Characteristically, a well-developed electric mark is a round or oval, shallow crater, bordered by raised areola of pale skin. This pale skin is due to arteriolar spasm caused by effects of the current on the vessel walls. There is mild hyperemia of the intact skin immediately beyond the pale skin. The floor of the crater is lined by a pale flattened skin.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 330

choices.text: Crocodile flash burn

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department with an unusual pattern of skin changes on his back after a house fire. The patient reports that he was wearing a synthetic fiber t-shirt when a flashover occurred as he was trying to extinguish the fire. The medical officer evaluating the patient recognizes this distinctive pattern as shown below.

 

 

What do these changes on the patient's body indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Filigree burns

 

Option D:

 

The picture shows the superficial, thin, irregular and tortuous markings on the skin. These markings have a general pattern resembling the branches of a tree hence they are Filigree or Lichtenberg flowers and are pathognomonic of lightning strike.

 

Explanation

 

Option A. Crocodile flash burns are a pattern of burns caused by high-voltage electrical arcs. They result in multiple, irregularly shaped lesions on the skin, resembling the scales of a crocodile, which is not the case in this image hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option B. Adipocere: It is a modification of putrefaction. The dead body looks soft, moist, whitish and translucent which is not the case in this image.

 

Option C. Mummification: It is a modification of putrefaction. It occurs in the absence of moisture in the air and continuous action of dry or warmed air. The skin is usually shrunken and contracted, dry, brittle, leathery and rusty-brown in color which is not the case in the above image.

 

Educational Objective

 

Filigree burns/ Arborescent or Lichtenberger’s flowers.

 

  • The pathognomonic feature of lightening
  • Superficial, thin, irregular, and tortuous markings on skin like branches of tree (fern like pattern).
  • They are caused by Slight staining of tissues by hemoglobin from lysed red blood cells (from superficial capillaries) along the path of electric current. Hence, they indicate the path taken by the discharge.
  • They do not follow the path of major blood vessels, but only follow the superficial capillaries.
  • Though called Filigree Burns but they are not actually burns.
  • They are transient erythema which appears within a few minutes to 1 hour of accident and gradually fades within 24 – 48 hours if the person survives.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 334

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department. On examination, he is found to have a branching, feather-like pattern of erythema over his torso and upper limbs. The attending physician notes that this distinctive pattern, sometimes referred to as a "Lichtenberg figure," is a rare finding and is typically associated with a specific cause. Understanding the pathophysiological mechanism behind this finding is crucial for the appropriate management of the patient. Which condition is the "Lichtenberg flower" pattern associated with?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lightening

 

Option B:

 

Lichtenberg’s flower (Also called as Filigree or Arborescent burns are Pathognomonic of lightening injury. These are Superficial, thin, irregular and tortuous marking over skin mainly over shoulders and flanks. They are caused by slight staining of tissue by hemoglobin from lysed RBCs along the path of current.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Electrocution - Electrocution refers to injury or death caused by electric shock. While high-voltage electrical injuries can sometimes create patterns on the skin due to the path of the electrical current, the unique, fern-like fractal patterns known as Lichtenberg figures are not typically used to describe injuries from man-made electrical sources.

 

Option C. Thermal burn - Thermal burns are caused by an external heat source, such as fire, hot metals, scalding liquids, or steam, and can damage the skin and tissues. They do not create the fern-like fractal pattern of Lichtenberg figures. The damage from thermal burns usually appears as reddened, blistered, or charred skin depending on the severity of the burn.

 

Option D.  Chemical burn - Chemical burns occur when skin or tissues are exposed to corrosive substances such as acids or alkalis. The resulting injuries can vary widely in appearance depending on the chemical involved but typically do not exhibit the fractal pattern seen with Lichtenberg figures. Instead, chemical burns might result in necrosis or ulceration of the skin.

 

Educational Objective

 

Lichtenberg’s flower (Filigree or Arbore scent burns)

 

  • Pathognomonic of lightening injury.
  • Superficial, thin, irregular and tortuous marking over skin mainly over shoulders and flanks.
  • Resembles branches of a tree (Fern like pattern) of erythema.
  • Not associated with burning.
  • May be caused by slight staining of tissue by hemoglobin from lysed RBCs along path of current.
  • Indicates the path taken by current but does not correspond to vascular channels.
  • Disappears in 1 or 2 days if survives.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 334

questions.text: After a house fire, a body is recovered and brought to the morgue for examination. The forensic expert notes that the body is in a pugilistic posture with the limbs drawn up and flexed, and the fists clenched. There is no other obvious evidence of trauma or foul play. Given the circumstances of the fire and the appearance of the body, the expert is determining the cause of this specific type of posture. What is the most likely explanation for the body's condition as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heat stiffening

 

Option A:

 

In the image above shows burn case, muscles became stiff as we can see flexion of elbows, clawing of fingers. This is due to Heat stiffening and attitude of the body is called Pugilistic or boxer`s attitude (as it looks like person is going for boxing).

 

Heat Stiffening (Pugilistic or Boxer’s attitude)

 

  • Shortening and stiffening of muscles due to coagulation of muscle proteins at body temp> 65° C
  • Flexion of elbows, knees and clenching of hand into a fist.
  • Much more Intense as compared to Rigor Mortis.
  • Occurs in both Antemortem as well as postmortem burns.
  • If Heat stiffening occurs, then rigor mortis does not occur.

 

Explanation

 

Option B. Rigor mortis: The degree of flexion is much lesser in rigor mortis as compared to heat stiffening. Image shows typical boxer’s attitude, which is characteristic of heat stiffening.

 

Option C. Cadaveric spasm: It occurs only in hands, but in the above image stiffening is seen in whole body hence it is incorrect.

 

Option D. Gas stiffening: It occurs during putrefaction due to accumulation of gases in the tissues which causes false rigidity resulting in stiff limbs. Gases produced by bacteria in the body cause it to swell and bloat but in picture above no such swelling or bloating is seen hence it is incorrect. Also, no other signs of putrefaction are seen

 

Educational Objective

 

Difference between Rigor mortis and Heat stiffening

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 322-323

questions.text: A 40-year-old cyclist who had been riding outdoors for hours suddenly collapses and loses consciousness. Bystanders mention that the cyclist was not adequately hydrating during the ride. Upon assessment, the individual's body temperature is 106°F (41°C). What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Heat Stroke

 

Option D:

 

Such a high body temperature of 106°F (41°C) goes with the diagnosis of heat stroke. In any of the other heat related conditions the body temperature is not so high. 

 

Explanation

 

Option A. Hypothermia: Here Body temperature < 35 °C (< 95 °F)

 

Option B. Sunburn: It just causes redness and burning sensation of the skin. it is not associated with systemic symptoms and such high body temperature.

 

Option C. Heat exhaustion: In Heat exhaustion the body temperature is slightly high but not to this extent. Symptoms are not so severe as in the question (collapse and loss of consciousness)

 

Educational Objective

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 319
